title:
Krylov Subspace Methods for Quantum Dynamics with Time-Dependent
  Generators

sections.text:
# Supplemental Material
## $\left(t, t^{\prime}\right)$ FORMALISM AND KRYLOV METHOD

In the $\left(t, t^{\prime}\right)$ formalism, we define a two-time dependent state as in Eq. (1). The operator $\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}$ is written by the unitary time-evolution operator $\hat{U}(t)$ for the Hamiltonian $\hat{H}(t)$ as

$$
\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}=-\hat{U}(t) i \partial_{t} \hat{U}^{\dagger}(t)
$$

Then, we can write for $|\phi(t)\rangle$ with $|\phi(0)\rangle=|\psi(0)\rangle$ as

$$
|\psi(s, t)\rangle=e^{-i s\left(\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)}|\phi(t)\rangle=\hat{U}(t) e^{-s \partial_{t}} \hat{U}^{\dagger}(t)|\phi(t)\rangle=\hat{U}(t) \hat{U}^{\dagger}(t-s)|\phi(t-s)\rangle
$$

Setting $s=t$, we find $|\psi(t, t)\rangle=\hat{U}(t)|\psi(0)\rangle=|\psi(t)\rangle$.
A different way to show that the operator $e^{-i s\left(\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)}$ is equivalent to the time evolution operator is to use the Lie-Trotter product formula as

$$
\begin{aligned}
e^{-i s\left(\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)} & =\lim _{M \rightarrow \infty}\left(e^{-i \frac{s}{M} \hat{H}(t)} e^{-\frac{s}{M} \partial_{t}}\right)^{M} \\
& =\lim _{M \rightarrow \infty} e^{-i \frac{s}{M} \hat{H}(t)} e^{-i \frac{s}{M} \hat{H}(t-s / M)} e^{-i \frac{s}{M} \hat{H}(t-2 s / M)} \cdots e^{-i \frac{s}{M} \hat{H}(t-(M-1) s / M)} e^{-s \partial_{t}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The last expression at $s=t$ takes the form of the time-ordered product, except the last factor. The last factor brings $|\phi(t)\rangle$ back to $|\phi(0)\rangle=|\psi(0)\rangle$. Thus, we can find the equivalence.

The two-time dependent state $|\psi(s, t)\rangle$ is more complicated than the original state $|\psi(t)\rangle$. This can be understood by using an orthonormal complete set $\{|n\rangle\}_{n=0,1, \ldots}$ as

$$
e^{-i s\left(\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)}|0\rangle=\hat{U}(t) \hat{U}^{\dagger}(t-s)|0\rangle=\sum_{n}|n(t)\rangle\langle n(t-s)| 0\rangle
$$

where $|n(t)\rangle=\hat{U}(t)|n\rangle$. This state generally contains contributions from all of $n=0,1, \ldots$ and is simplified to $|0(t)\rangle$ at $s=t$.

The time-evolution law of $|\psi(s, t)\rangle$ is written as

$$
i \partial_{s}|\psi(s, t)\rangle=\left(\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)|\psi(s, t)\rangle
$$

This equation can be solved if we can find the eigenstates and eigenvalues of $\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}$. It is a formidable task and we can apply the Krylov algorithm to tridiagonalize the operator. By using the Krylov basis introduced in Eq. (2), we define

$$
\hat{F}(t)=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1}\left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle\langle k|=\left(\left|K_{0}(t)\right\rangle,\left|K_{1}(t)\right\rangle, \ldots,\left|K_{d-1}(t)\right\rangle\right)
$$

When the dimension of the Hilbert space is denoted by $N, \hat{F}(t)$ is a $N \times d$ matrix and satisfies $\hat{F}^{\dagger}(t) \hat{F}(t)=\hat{I}_{d}$, where $\hat{I}_{d}$ is the identity operator in the $d$ dimensional space. We note that $\hat{F}(t) \hat{F}^{\dagger}(t)$ is not necessarily equal to the identity operator in the Hilbert space. Then, the definition of the basis vector leads to the relation

$$
\left(\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right) \hat{F}(t)=\hat{F}(t)\left(\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)
$$

Expanding the state in the Krylov basis is equivalent to the transformation

$$
|\psi(s, t)\rangle=\hat{F}(t)|\varphi(s, t)\rangle
$$

The transformed vector $|\varphi(s, t)\rangle$ has the size of the Krylov dimension. It satisfies

$$
i \partial_{s}|\varphi(s, t)\rangle=\left(\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)|\varphi(s, t)\rangle
$$

with the initial condition $|\varphi(0, t)\rangle=|0\rangle$. The two-time state is written as

$$
|\psi(s, t)\rangle=\hat{F}(t) e^{-i s\left(\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)}|0\rangle=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1}\left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle\langle k| e^{-i s\left(\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)}|0\rangle
$$

One of the prominent features of the Krylov method is that some physical quantities are described only by the Lanczos coefficients. A typical example that is known for the time-independent Hamiltonian is the survival amplitude [4]. This property still holds in the time-dependent case, as we see from the relation $\left\langle K_{0}(t) \mid \psi(s, t)\right\rangle=\langle 0| e^{-i s\left(\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)}|0\rangle$. The right-hand side is represented by the Lanczos coefficients and their derivatives. We can find differential equations for the Lanczos coefficients if we know the overlap $\left\langle K_{0}(t) \mid \psi(s, t)\right\rangle$.

# KRYLOV METHOD FOR THE DENSITY OPERATOR 

In the standard applications of the Krylov subspace method to quantum dynamics, it is common to resort to the Heisenberg picture and describe the time evolution of an operator rather, as opposed to describing the time evolution of the quantum state. The Heisenberg representation of a quantum operator $\hat{X}$ evolving under a time-independent Hamiltonian $\hat{H}$ is given by $e^{i \hat{H} t} \hat{X} e^{-i \hat{H} t}$. In the time-dependent case, we cannot apply the same method as the time-evolution operator requires time-ordering given the noncommutative property $\left[\hat{H}(t), \hat{H}\left(t^{\prime}\right)\right] \neq 0$.

However, treating the density operator $\hat{\rho}(t)$ is still possible. The density operator satisfies the von Neumann equation,

$$
i \partial_{t} \hat{\rho}(t)=[\hat{H}(t), \hat{\rho}(t)]
$$

We can use the recurrence relation

$$
b_{k+1}(t) \hat{O}_{k+1}(t)=\left(\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right) \hat{O}_{k}(t)-b_{k}(t) \hat{O}_{k-1}(t)
$$

where $\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{H}(t)(\cdot)=[\hat{H}(t),(\cdot)]$. The Lanczos coefficients are given by $b_{k}(t)=\left(\hat{O}_{k-1}(t),\left(\hat{\mathcal{L}}_{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right) \hat{O}_{k}(t)\right)$ with a properly-defined inner product $(\hat{A}, \hat{B})$ for an arbitrary set of operators $\hat{A}$ and $\hat{B}$.

When the density operator is expanded as

$$
\hat{\rho}(t)=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1} \varphi_{k}(t) \hat{O}_{k}(t)
$$

the vector $|\varphi(t)\rangle=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1}|k\rangle \varphi_{k}(t)$ satisfies $i \partial_{t}|\varphi(t)\rangle=\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)|\varphi(t)\rangle$ with

$$
\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)=\sum_{k=1}^{d-1} b_{k}(t)(|k\rangle\langle k-1|+|k-1\rangle\langle k|)=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}0 & b_{1}(t) & 0 & & & \\ b_{1}(t) & 0 & b_{2}(t) & & & \\ 0 & b_{2}(t) & 0 & & & \\ & & & \ddots & & \\ & & & & 0 & b_{d-1}(t) \\ & & & & b_{d-1}(t) & 0\end{array}\right)
$$

The diagonal components are absent in the present case, and the coefficient $b_{k}(t)$ is different from the corresponding one $b_{k}(t)$ for the state $|\psi(t)\rangle$. We further note that $\hat{O}_{k}(t)$ is neither Hermitian nor positive definite. Since the density operator satisfies the normalization condition $\operatorname{Tr} \hat{\rho}(t)=1$, we have several additional conditions, such as $\sum_{k=0}^{d-1} \varphi_{k}(t) \operatorname{Tr} \hat{O}_{k}(t)=1$

## KRYLOV SPEED LIMIT INEQUALITY

To derive Eq. (7), we start by evaluating the time derivative of the angle defined in Eq. (6), which yields the identity relation

$$
\begin{aligned}
-2 \partial_{t} \Theta_{n}(t) \sin \Theta_{n}(t) \cos \Theta_{n}(t) & =-i \sum_{k=0}^{n}\left(\langle\varphi(t)| k\rangle\langle k| \hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)|\varphi(t)\rangle-\langle\varphi(t)| \hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)|k\rangle\langle k| \varphi(t)\rangle\right) \\
& =-i b_{n+1}(t)\left(\langle\varphi(t)| n\rangle\langle n+1| \varphi(t)\rangle-\langle\varphi(t)| n+1\rangle\langle n| \varphi(t)\rangle\right) \\
& =-2 b_{n+1}(t) \operatorname{Im} \varphi_{n}(t) \varphi_{n+1}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

and the inequality

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\partial_{t} \Theta_{n}(t)\right| \sin \Theta_{n}(t) \cos \Theta_{n}(t) & \leq b_{n+1}(t)\left|\varphi_{n}(t)\right|\left|\varphi_{n+1}(t)\right| \\
& =b_{n+1}(t) \sqrt{\sin ^{2} \Theta_{n}(t)-\sin ^{2} \Theta_{n+1}(t)} \sqrt{\cos ^{2} \Theta_{n}(t)-\cos ^{2} \Theta_{n-1}(t)}
\end{aligned}
$$

The equality holds when $\varphi_{n}(t) \varphi_{n+1}(t)$ is pure imaginary. This condition is satisfied when $a_{k}(t)=0$. In that case, the equation for $\varphi_{n}(t)$ reads

$$
i \partial_{t} \varphi_{n}(t)=b_{n}(t) \varphi_{n-1}(t)+b_{n+1}(t) \varphi_{n+1}(t)
$$

This equation can be solved with the initial condition $\varphi_{n}(0)=\delta_{n, 0}$. The even components $\varphi_{0}(t), \varphi_{2}(t), \ldots$ are real and the odd components $\varphi_{1}(t), \varphi_{3}(t), \ldots$ are pure imaginary. Thus, we obtain Eq. (7).

# SOLVABLE EXAMPLES
## Single spin

We treat the single spin system, generally written as

$$
\hat{H}(t)=h(t) \boldsymbol{n}(t) \cdot \hat{\boldsymbol{S}}
$$

$\hat{\boldsymbol{S}}=\left(\hat{S}^{x}, \hat{S}^{y}, \hat{S}^{z}\right)$ represents the spin operator with $\hat{\boldsymbol{S}}^{2}=S(S+1)$. The applied external field is characterized by the absolute value $h(t)$ and the direction $\boldsymbol{n}(t)=(\sin \theta(t) \cos \varphi(t), \sin \theta(t) \sin \varphi(t), \cos \theta(t))$. The Hilbert space is generally spanned by the eigenstates of $\hat{S}^{z}$ satisfying

$$
\hat{S}^{z}|m\rangle=m|m\rangle
$$

with $m=-S,-S+1, \ldots, S$. We set $\hat{H}(0)=h(0) \hat{S}^{z}$ and the initial state as $|\psi(0)\rangle=|S\rangle$.

## Fixed z-basis

In the fixed $z$-basis, the Hamiltonian is represented in a tridiagonal form, which means that we can naturally obtain a Krylov basis. When the initial basis is set as $\left|K_{0}(t)\right\rangle=|S\rangle$, we obtain

$$
\left(\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}\right)\left|K_{0}(t)\right\rangle=\hat{H}(t)|S\rangle=S h(t) \cos \theta(t)|S\rangle+\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2 S} h(t) \sin \theta(t) e^{i \varphi(t)}|S-1\rangle
$$

This gives

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{0}(t)=S h(t) \cos \theta(t) \\
& b_{1}(t)=\frac{\sqrt{2 S}}{2} h(t) \sin \theta(t) \\
& \left|K_{1}(t)\right\rangle=e^{i \varphi(t)}|S-1\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

In a similar way, we can calculate the higher-order contributions. The point in the present example is that the Hamiltonian is written in terms of three kinds of operators and we can generally write its action in a given state $|m\rangle$ as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{H}(t)|m\rangle & =h\left[S^{z} \cos \theta+\frac{1}{2}\left(S^{+} e^{-i \varphi}+S^{-} e^{i \varphi}\right)\right]|m\rangle \\
& =h m \cos \theta|m\rangle+\frac{h}{2} e^{-i \varphi} \sqrt{(S-m)(S+m+1)}|m+1\rangle+\frac{h}{2} e^{i \varphi} \sqrt{(S+m)(S-m+1)}|m-1\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

The state vector $|m\rangle$ is time-independent, and taking the time derivative to the state vector does not give any contribution. As a result, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=e^{i k \varphi(t)}|S-k\rangle \quad(k=0,1, \ldots, 2 S) \\
& a_{k}(t)=(S-k) h(t) \cos \theta(t)+k \dot{\varphi}(t) \quad(k=0,1, \ldots, 2 S) \\
& b_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{2} h(t) \sin \theta(t) \sqrt{k(d-k)} \quad(k=1, \ldots, 2 S)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the dot denotes the time derivative. The Krylov dimension is equal to the Hilbert space dimension, i.e., $d=2 S+1$.

# Instantaneous eigenstate basis 

The instantaneous eigenstates of the Hamiltonian are given by the eigenstates of rotated- $\hat{S}^{z}$ satisfying

$$
\hat{R}(t) \hat{S}^{z} \hat{R}^{\dagger}(t)|m(t)\rangle=m|m(t)\rangle
$$

with $m=-S,-S+1, \ldots, S$. The rotation operator $\hat{R}(t)$ is written as

$$
\hat{R}(t)=\exp \left(-i \theta(t) \hat{\boldsymbol{S}} \cdot \boldsymbol{e}_{\varphi}(t)\right)
$$

with $\boldsymbol{e}_{\varphi}(t)=(-\sin \varphi(t), \cos \varphi(t), 0)$.
We set the initial Krylov basis as

$$
\left|K_{0}(t)\right\rangle=|S(t)\rangle
$$

We apply $\hat{H}(t)-i \partial_{t}$ to this basis. The action of the Hamiltonian only gives an eigenvalue, and we need to consider the time derivative of the instantaneous eigenstates. The time derivative is closely related to the counterdiabatic term [23-25, 28, 29]. Generally, for possible instantaneous eigenstates $|m(t)\rangle$, we can write

$$
i \partial_{t}|m(t)\rangle=\hat{H}_{\mathrm{CD}}(t)|m(t)\rangle+|m(t)\rangle i\langle m(t)| \hat{m}(t)\rangle
$$

In the present case, the counterdiabatic term $\hat{H}_{\mathrm{CD}}(t)$ is given by [25]

$$
\hat{H}_{\mathrm{CD}}(t)=\boldsymbol{n}(t) \times \dot{\boldsymbol{n}}(t) \cdot \hat{\boldsymbol{S}}
$$

and we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
i \partial_{t}|m(t)\rangle= & -\frac{i}{2}(\dot{\theta}(t)-i \dot{\varphi}(t) \sin \theta(t)) e^{-i \varphi(t)} \sqrt{(S-m)(S+m+1)}|m+1(t)\rangle \\
& +\frac{i}{2}(\dot{\theta}(t)+i \dot{\varphi}(t) \sin \theta(t)) e^{i \varphi(t)} \sqrt{(S+m)(S-m+1)}|m-1(t)\rangle-m \dot{\varphi}(t)(1-\cos \theta(t))|m(t)\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

Comparing this to the recurrence relation of the Krylov basis, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=(-i)^{k} e^{i k\left(\varphi(t)+\varphi_{0}(t)\right)}|S-k(t)\rangle \quad(k=0,1, \ldots, 2 S) \\
& a_{k}(t)=(S-k)\left[h(t)+\dot{\varphi}(t)(1-\cos \theta(t))\right]+k\left(\dot{\varphi}(t)+\dot{\phi}_{0}(t)\right) \quad(k=0,1, \ldots, 2 S) \\
& b_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{\dot{\theta}^{2}(t)+\dot{\varphi}^{2}(t) \sin ^{2} \theta(t)} \sqrt{k(d-k)} \quad(k=1, \ldots, 2 S)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d=2 S+1$ represents the Krylov dimension and

$$
e^{i \phi_{0}(t)}=\frac{\dot{\theta}(t)+i \dot{\varphi}(t) \sin \theta(t)}{\sqrt{\dot{\theta}^{2}(t)+\dot{\varphi}^{2}(t) \sin ^{2} \theta(t)}}
$$

## Harmonic oscillator with translation

We consider a one-dimensional single-particle in a harmonic oscillator potential. The center of the potential is changed as a function of time keeping the potential shape invariant. The Hamiltonian is given by

$$
\hat{H}(t)=\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{p}^{2}+\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2}\left(\hat{x}-x_{0}(t)\right)^{2}
$$

We set $x_{0}(0)=0$ and choose the initial state as the ground state of $\hat{H}(0)$.

# Fixed eigenstate basis 

The Hamiltonian is written as

$$
\hat{H}(t)=\left(\hat{a}^{\dagger} \hat{a}+\frac{1}{2}\right) \omega-\sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{2}} \omega x_{0}(t)\left(\hat{a}+\hat{a}^{\dagger}\right)+\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2} x_{0}^{2}(t)
$$

Here, we define the lowering operator

$$
\hat{a}=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{2}} \hat{x}+\frac{i}{\sqrt{2 m \omega}} \hat{p}
$$

and the raising operator $\hat{a}^{\dagger}$. They give $\hat{a}|n\rangle=\sqrt{n}|n-1\rangle$ and $\hat{a}^{\dagger}|n\rangle=\sqrt{n+1}|n+1\rangle$ for the number state $|n\rangle$ satisfying $\hat{a}^{\dagger} \hat{a}|n\rangle=n|n\rangle$.

The number state basis $\{|n\rangle\}$ allows us to write the Hamiltonian in a tridiagonalized form. When we set $\left|K_{0}\right\rangle=|0\rangle$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=\left(-\frac{\dot{x}_{0}(t)}{\left|\dot{x}_{0}(t)\right|}\right)^{k}|k\rangle \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& a_{k}(t)=\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right) \omega+\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2} x_{0}^{2}(t) \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& b_{k}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{2}} \omega\left|x_{0}(t)\right| \sqrt{k} \quad(k=1,2, \ldots)
\end{aligned}
$$

Instantaneous eigenstate basis
The Hamiltonian can also be written with respect to the operator at each time defined as

$$
\hat{a}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{2}}\left(\hat{x}-x_{0}(t)\right)+\frac{i}{\sqrt{2 m \omega}} \hat{p}
$$

We obtain

$$
\hat{H}(t)=\left(\hat{a}^{\dagger}(t) \hat{a}(t)+\frac{1}{2}\right) \omega
$$

and the instantaneous eigenstates are given by $|n(t)\rangle$ with $n=0,1, \ldots$, where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{a}(t)|n(t)\rangle=\sqrt{n}|n-1(t)\rangle \\
& \hat{a}^{\dagger}(t)|n(t)\rangle=\sqrt{n+1}|n+1(t)\rangle
\end{aligned}
$$

The time derivative of the instantaneous eigenstate is written as in Eq. (S31). The counterdiabatic term in the present case is given by [27]

$$
\hat{H}_{\mathrm{CD}}(t)=\dot{x}_{0}(t) \hat{p}=-i \sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{2}} \dot{x}_{0}(t)\left(\hat{a}(t)-\hat{a}^{\dagger}(t)\right)
$$

This has a tridiagonal form in the instantaneous eigenstate basis. When we set $\left|K_{0}(t)\right\rangle=|0(t)\rangle$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=\left(-i \frac{\dot{x}_{0}(t)}{\left|\dot{x}_{0}(t)\right|}\right)^{k}|k(t)\rangle \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& a_{k}(t)=\left(k+\frac{1}{2}\right) \omega \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& b_{k}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega}{2}}\left|\dot{x}_{0}(t)\right| \sqrt{k} \quad(k=1,2, \ldots)
\end{aligned}
$$

# Harmonic oscillator with dilation 

Let us again consider a Harmonic oscillator system. We set $x_{0}(t)=0$ and make the frequency $\omega$ a time-dependent function. The Hamiltonian is given by

$$
\hat{H}(t)=\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{p}^{2}+\frac{m}{2} \omega^{2}(t) \hat{x}^{2}
$$

The initial state is set as the ground state of the initial Hamiltonian.

## Fixed eigenstate basis

We write the Hamiltonian in terms of the annihilation operator at $t=0$ :

$$
\hat{a}=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega(0)}{2}} \hat{x}+\frac{i}{\sqrt{2 m \omega(0)}} \hat{p}
$$

We obtain

$$
\hat{H}(t)=\frac{\omega^{2}(t)+\omega^{2}(0)}{2 \omega(0)}\left(\hat{a}^{\dagger} \hat{a}+\frac{1}{2}\right)+\frac{\omega^{2}(t)-\omega^{2}(0)}{4 \omega(0)}\left(\left(\hat{a}^{\dagger}\right)^{2}+\hat{a}^{2}\right)
$$

Since the last term lowers or raises the state by two, the Krylov basis is given by $|2 k\rangle$. When we set $\left|K_{0}(t)\right\rangle=|0\rangle$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=\left(\frac{\omega^{2}(t)-\omega^{2}(0)}{\left|\omega^{2}(t)-\omega^{2}(0)\right|}\right)^{k}|2 k\rangle \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& a_{k}(t)=\left(2 k+\frac{1}{2}\right) \frac{\omega^{2}(t)+\omega^{2}(0)}{2 \omega(0)} \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& b_{k}(t)=\frac{\left|\omega^{2}(t)-\omega^{2}(0)\right|}{4 \omega(0)} \sqrt{2 k(2 k-1)} \quad(k=1,2, \ldots)
\end{aligned}
$$

Instantaneous eigenstate basis
The Hamiltonian is written with respect to the operator

$$
\hat{a}(t)=\sqrt{\frac{m \omega(t)}{2}} \hat{x}+\frac{i}{\sqrt{2 m \omega(t)}} \hat{p}
$$

The counterdiabatic term is given by [27]

$$
\hat{H}_{\mathrm{CD}}(t)=i \frac{\dot{\omega}(t)}{4 \omega(t)}\left(\hat{a}^{2}(t)-\left(\hat{a}^{\dagger}\right)^{2}(t)\right)
$$

When we set $\left|K_{0}(t)\right\rangle=|0(t)\rangle$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=\left(i \frac{\dot{\omega}(t)}{|\dot{\omega}(t)|}\right)^{k}|2 k(t)\rangle \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& a_{k}(t)=\left(2 k+\frac{1}{2}\right) \omega(t) \quad(k=0,1, \ldots) \\
& b_{k}(t)=\frac{|\dot{\omega}(t)|}{4 \omega(t)} \sqrt{2 k(2 k-1)} \quad(k=1,2, \ldots)
\end{aligned}
$$

# An example of speed limit 

As an exactly solvable model, we treat the Hamiltonian of the harmonic oscillator potential in Eq. (S38) with

$$
x_{0}(t)=v t
$$

As a Krylov basis set, we use the instantaneous set in Eqs. (S49), (S50), and (S51). The Lanczos coefficients are independent of $t$ and we can find the exact form of $\varphi_{k}(t)$.

Since the Hamiltonian is written as

$$
\hat{H}(t)=e^{-i v t \hat{p}}\left(\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{p}^{2}+\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2} \hat{x}^{2}\right) e^{i v t \hat{p}}
$$

the equation for $|\psi(t)\rangle$ can be solved by moving to the rotating frame. We can write

$$
|\psi(t)\rangle=e^{-i v t \hat{p}} e^{-i \hat{H}_{v} t}|0\rangle
$$

where

$$
\hat{H}_{v}=\frac{1}{2 m}(\hat{p}-m v)^{2}+\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2} \hat{x}^{2}-\frac{m v^{2}}{2}=e^{-i m v \hat{x}}\left(\frac{1}{2 m} \hat{p}^{2}+\frac{m \omega^{2}}{2} \hat{x}^{2}-\frac{m v^{2}}{2}\right) e^{i m v \hat{x}}
$$

When $v>0$, the Krylov basis is written as

$$
\left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=(-i)^{k}|k(t)\rangle=(-i)^{k} e^{-i v t \hat{p}}|k\rangle
$$

Then, the overlap is written as

$$
\varphi_{k}(t)=i^{k} e^{i m v^{2} t / 2} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} e^{-i(n+1 / 2) \omega t}\langle k| e^{i m v \hat{x}}|n\rangle\langle n| e^{-i m v \hat{x}}|0\rangle
$$

The matrix element of $e^{i m v \hat{x}}$ with respect to the eigenstate basis can be calculated by using the coherent state. We obtain

$$
\langle k| e^{i m v \hat{x}}|n\rangle=e^{-\gamma^{2} / 2} \sum_{l=0}^{\min (n, k)} \frac{\sqrt{n!k!}}{l!(n-l)!(k-l)!}(i \gamma)^{n+k-2 l}
$$

where

$$
\gamma=\sqrt{\frac{m v^{2}}{2 \omega}}
$$

We substitute this expression to Eq. (S68). The sums over $n$ and $l$ can be performed by inverting their order as

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \sum_{l=0}^{\min (n, k)}(\ldots)=\sum_{n=0}^{k} \sum_{l=0}^{n}(\ldots)+\sum_{n=k+1}^{\infty} \sum_{l=0}^{k}(\ldots)=\sum_{l=0}^{k} \sum_{n=l}^{\infty}(\ldots)
$$

We obtain

$$
\varphi_{k}(t)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{k!}}\left[-\gamma\left(1-e^{-i \omega t}\right)\right]^{k} e^{-\gamma^{2}\left(1-e^{-i \omega t}\right)} e^{i\left(\gamma^{2}-1 / 2\right) \omega t}
$$

The probability for the state $|\psi(t)\rangle$ at the $k$ th order of the Krylov basis is given by

$$
\left|\varphi_{k}(t)\right|^{2}=\frac{1}{k!}\left(2 \gamma \sin \frac{\omega t}{2}\right)^{2 k} \exp \left[-\left(2 \gamma \sin \frac{\omega t}{2}\right)^{2}\right] \sim\left(\frac{2 \gamma \sin \frac{\omega t}{2}}{\sqrt{k}}\right)^{2 k} \exp \left[-\left(2 \gamma \sin \frac{\omega t}{2}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

The last expression is applied for $k \gg 1$. This allows us to estimate the propagation limit. The time scale is set by

$$
2 \gamma \sin \frac{\omega t}{2}=\sqrt{k}
$$

![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 4. Spreading in the Krylov space for the harmonic-oscillator Hamiltonian in Eq. (S38) with Eq. (S63). The solid line denotes a bound determined by Eq. (S77) and the dashed line denotes Eq. (S74).

On the other hand, $b_{k}(t)$ in the present case is given by

$$
b_{k}(t)=\omega \gamma \sqrt{k}
$$

The general propagation limit discussed in the main text is written as

$$
\Theta_{n}(t) \leq \exp \left[-n \ln \left(\frac{\sqrt{n}}{\gamma \omega t}\right)\right]
$$

for $n \gg 1$ and the time scale is identified as

$$
\gamma \omega t=\sqrt{n}
$$

This is consistent with Eq. (S74) at $\omega t \ll 1$. The equality in Eq. (S76) holds only when $a_{k}(t)=0$. In the present case, we have $a_{k}(t)=(k+1 / 2) \omega$. Then, it is reasonable that the scale identified from Eq. (S76) coincides with Eq. (S74) at $\omega t \ll 1$.

In Fig. 4, we plot $\Theta_{n}(t)$. Equation (S77) makes sense as a propagation limit at small $\omega t$. Equation (S74) determined from the exact solution gives a good result in the whole range of $\omega t$.

# COMPLEXITY ALGEBRA
## Closed algebra

For a given set of Lanczos coefficients, we can discuss the complexity algebra. By using the phase transformation mentioned in the main body, we change the generator $\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)$ as

$$
\hat{\mathcal{L}}(t)=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
0 & b_{1}(t) e^{i \delta_{1}(t)} & 0 & \\
b_{1}(t) e^{-i \delta_{1}(t)} & 0 & b_{2}(t) e^{i \delta_{2}(t)} & \\
0 & b_{2}(t) e^{-i \delta_{2}(t)} & 0 & \\
& & & \ddots
\end{array}\right)
$$

where $\delta_{k}(t)=-\int_{0}^{t} d s\left(a_{k}(s)-a_{k-1}(s)\right)$. The corresponding current operator is given by

$$
\hat{\mathcal{J}}(t)=-i\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
0 & -b_{1}(t) e^{i \delta_{1}(t)} & 0 & \\
b_{1} e^{-i \delta_{1}(t)} & 0 & -b_{2}(t) e^{i \delta_{2}(t)} & \\
0 & b_{2}(t) e^{-i \delta_{2}(t)} & 0 & \\
& & & \ddots
\end{array}\right)
$$

As we show in the main body, these operators are related to each other by the commutator with the complexity operator

$$
\hat{\mathcal{K}}=\left(\begin{array}{llll}
0 & 0 & 0 & \\
0 & 1 & 0 & \\
0 & 0 & 2 & \\
& & & \ddots
\end{array}\right)
$$

The spread complexity is written as $K(t)=\langle\varphi(t)| \hat{\mathcal{K}}|\varphi(t)\rangle$. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {[\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}, \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t)]=i \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t)} \\
& {[\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t), \hat{\mathcal{K}}]=i \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t)}
\end{aligned}
$$

These relations hold generally. Furthermore, in the three systems studied in the previous sections, the commutator of $\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}$ and $\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}$ takes the form

$$
[\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t), \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t)]=-i(\alpha(t) \hat{\mathcal{K}}+\gamma(t))
$$

These commutation relations are not enough to describe the time evolution of the spread complexity as knowledge of the time dependence of the Lanczos coefficients is additionally required. The equation is simplified when we impose

$$
\begin{aligned}
& b_{k}(t)=b(t) c_{k} \\
& \delta_{1}(t)=\delta_{2}(t)=\delta_{3}(t)=\cdots=: \delta(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

These conditions are satisfied in all the examples described in the previous section. For example, for the single spin Hamiltonian in the instantaneous eigenstate basis, we can write

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \alpha(t)=-\left(\hat{\theta}^{2}(t)+\hat{\varphi}^{2}(t) \sin ^{2} \theta(t)\right) \\
& \gamma(t)=-S \alpha(t) \\
& b(t)=\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{-\alpha(t)} \\
& c_{k}=\sqrt{k(d-k)} \\
& \dot{\delta}(t)=h(t)-\dot{\varphi}(t) \cos \theta(t)-\dot{\phi}_{0}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the remaining part of the present section, we treat this case.

# Time evolution of Heisenberg operators 

We consider the Heisenberg representation of three operators

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)=\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}^{\dagger}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}(t) \\
& \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)=\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}^{\dagger}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}(t) \\
& \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)=\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}^{\dagger}(t) \hat{\mathcal{K}} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}(t)$ is the unitary time-evolution operator satisfying

$$
i \partial_{t} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}(t)=\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}(t)
$$

with $\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}(0)=1$. The spread complexity is written as $K(t)=\langle\varphi(t)| \hat{\mathcal{K}}|\varphi(t)\rangle=\langle 0| \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)|0\rangle$. We apply the time derivative operator to these operators. Due to the above-mentioned structure of the Lanczos coefficients, $\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t)$ is obtained from the time derivative of $\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t)$ and vice versa:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \partial_{t} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t)=\frac{\dot{b}(t)}{b(t)} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t)+\dot{\delta}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t) \\
& \partial_{t} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t)=\frac{\dot{b}(t)}{b(t)} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{J}}}(t)-\dot{\delta}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{L}}}(t)
\end{aligned}
$$

We have

$$
\partial_{t}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{\hat{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\dot{\hat{\mathcal{J}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{\delta}(t) & \dot{\delta}(t) & 0 \\
-\dot{\delta}(t) & \dot{\delta}(t) & \alpha(t) \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\hat{\hat{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\hat{\hat{\mathcal{J}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)
\end{array}\right)+\gamma(t)\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

The current is written by the time derivative of the Krylov complexity as $\dot{\hat{\mathcal{J}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)=\partial_{t} \hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)$. This relation comes from the commutation relation in Eq. (S81) and holds generally.

We consider the simplest case for the single spin system

$$
\theta(t)=\omega t, \quad \varphi(t)=0, \quad \dot{h}(t)=0
$$

The differential equation

$$
\partial_{t}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{\hat{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\hat{\hat{\mathcal{J}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{ccc}
0 & h & 0 \\
-h & 0 & -\omega^{2} \\
0 & 1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\dot{\hat{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\dot{\hat{\mathcal{J}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
\hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)
\end{array}\right)+S \omega^{2}\left(\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

is solved analytically as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)= & -\frac{h\left[1-\cos \left(\sqrt{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} t\right)\right]}{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} \dot{\mathcal{L}}(0)+\frac{\sin \left(\sqrt{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} t\right)}{\sqrt{h^{2}+\omega^{2}}} \dot{\mathcal{J}}(0) \\
& +\frac{h^{2}+\omega^{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} t\right)}{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} \tilde{\mathcal{K}}+S \frac{\omega^{2}\left[1-\cos \left(\sqrt{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} t\right)\right]}{h^{2}+\omega^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \dot{\hat{\mathcal{J}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)=\partial_{t} \hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t) \\
& \dot{\hat{\mathcal{L}}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)=h\left(\hat{\mathcal{K}}^{\mathrm{H}}(t)-\tilde{\mathcal{K}}\right)+\dot{\mathcal{L}}(0)
\end{aligned}
$$

The spread complexity is given by

$$
K(t)=S \frac{\omega^{2}\left[1-\cos \left(\sqrt{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} t\right)\right]}{h^{2}+\omega^{2}}
$$

# Operator quantum speed limit 

In [42], the operator quantum speed limit was derived. When the formula is applied to the complexity operator $\tilde{\mathcal{K}}$, we can write

$$
\arccos \left(\frac{\operatorname{Tr} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{K}}}^{\dagger}(t) \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{K}}} \tilde{\mathcal{U}}(t)}{\operatorname{Tr} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{K}}}^{2}}\right) \leq \int_{0}^{t} d s \sqrt{\frac{\operatorname{Tr} \tilde{\mathcal{J}}^{2}(s)}{\operatorname{Tr} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{K}}}^{2}}}
$$

where

$$
\hat{\tilde{\mathcal{K}}}=\tilde{\mathcal{K}}-\frac{1}{d} \operatorname{Tr} \tilde{\mathcal{K}}
$$

This speed limit relation makes sense when $d$ is finite. In the single spin case, we can write

$$
\arccos \left(\frac{\operatorname{Tr} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{U}}}^{\dagger}(t) \tilde{\mathcal{K}} \tilde{\mathcal{U}}(t)}{\operatorname{Tr} \hat{\tilde{\mathcal{K}}}^{2}}\right) \leq \int_{0}^{t} d s \sqrt{\theta^{2}(s)+\dot{\varphi}^{2}(s) \sin ^{2} \theta(s)}
$$

In the time-dependent case, the equality condition is not satisfied. For example, when we use Eq. (S98), we obtain

$$
\arccos \left(\frac{h^{2}+\omega^{2} \cos \left(\sqrt{h^{2}+\omega^{2}} t\right)}{h^{2}+\omega^{2}}\right) \leq \omega t
$$

The equality is satisfied only in the trivial case $h=0$.

# KRYLOV METHOD FOR DISCRETE-TIME SYSTEMS
## Time evolution operator

In the discrete-time case, the Krylov basis is produced by the Arnoldi iteration procedure. Then, by using the Arnoldi coefficients, we can consider the time evolution of the transformed state as $\left|\varphi^{k}\right\rangle=\hat{\mathcal{U}}^{k-1}\left|\varphi^{k-1}\right\rangle$, with $\left|\varphi^{0}\right\rangle=|0\rangle$. The Arnoldi procedure is shown in the main body. Here, we show how to construct $\hat{\mathcal{U}}^{k}$ in the iteration procedure.

We decompose the operator as

$$
\hat{\mathcal{U}}^{k-1}=\sum_{l=0}^{\min (k-1, d-1)}\left|u_{l}^{k-1}\right\rangle\langle l|
$$

to write

$$
\left|\varphi^{k}\right\rangle=\hat{\mathcal{U}}^{k-1}\left|\varphi^{k-1}\right\rangle=\sum_{l=0}^{\min (k-1, d-1)}\left|u_{l}^{k-1}\right\rangle \varphi_{l}^{k-1}
$$

We produce the first vector from the Arnoldi procedure, as

$$
\left|u_{0}^{k-1}\right\rangle=|0\rangle z_{0}^{k-1}+|1\rangle \sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}^{k-1}\right|^{2}}
$$

Then, a perpendicular vector is defined as an auxiliary vector:

$$
\left|v_{0}^{k-1}\right\rangle=-|0\rangle \sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}^{k-1}\right|^{2}}+|1\rangle\left(z_{0}^{k-1}\right)^{*}
$$

We repeat the same procedure with

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|u_{l}^{k-1}\right\rangle=\left|v_{l-1}^{k-1}\right\rangle z_{l}^{k-1}+|l+1\rangle \sqrt{1-\left|z_{l}^{k-1}\right|^{2}} \\
& \left|v_{l}^{k-1}\right\rangle=-\left|v_{l-1}^{k-1}\right\rangle \sqrt{1-\left|z_{l}^{k-1}\right|^{2}}+|l+1\rangle\left(z_{l}^{k-1}\right)^{*}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $l=1,2, \ldots, d-2$. Finally, for $l=d-1$, we use

$$
\left|u_{d-1}^{k-1}\right\rangle=\left|v_{d-2}^{k-1}\right\rangle
$$

By completing this procedure, we can obtain all components of $\hat{\mathcal{U}}^{k-1}$.
The first three vectors are written explicitly as

$$
\hat{\mathcal{U}}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
z_{0} & -\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} z_{1} & \sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} \sqrt{1-\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}} z_{2} & \cdots \\
\sqrt{1-\left|z_{0}\right|^{2}} & z_{0}^{*} z_{1} & -z_{0}^{*} \sqrt{1-\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}} z_{2} & \cdots \\
0 & \sqrt{1-\left|z_{1}\right|^{2}} & z_{1}^{*} z_{2} & \cdots \\
0 & 0 & \sqrt{1-\left|z_{2}\right|^{2}} & \cdots \\
\vdots & \vdots & \vdots & \ddots
\end{array}\right)
$$

which satisfies $\hat{\mathcal{U}}^{\dagger} \hat{\mathcal{U}}=1$.

## One-dimensional quantum Ising model

We apply the discrete-time formalism to the one-dimensional quantum Ising model in Eq. (14). It is well known that the model is integrable, and it can be written as a free-fermion Hamiltonian, as described, e.g., in [57]. The system is shown to be equivalent to the sum of independent two-level systems. We assume $N$ is even and impose the periodic boundary condition $\tilde{Z}_{N+1}=\tilde{Z}_{1}$. When the discrete-time is denoted as $t=-t_{Q}+k \Delta t$ with $k=0,1, \ldots, M$, the final time is given by $t_{Q}=M \Delta t / 2$. The effective Hamiltonian is written as

$$
\hat{H}^{k}=\sum_{n=1}^{N / 2}\left(-\epsilon_{n}^{k} \tilde{Z}^{n}+v_{n}^{k} \tilde{X}^{n}\right)
$$

where $\hat{Z}^{n}$ and $\hat{X}^{n}$ are Pauli operators at each site $n$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\epsilon_{n}^{k} & =2 h \sqrt{\left(1-\frac{2 k}{M}\right)^{2}+4\left(1-\frac{k}{M}\right) \frac{k}{M} \sin ^{2} \frac{p_{n}}{2}} \\
v_{n}^{k} & =-\frac{h^{2} \sin p_{n}}{t_{Q}\left(\epsilon_{n}^{k}\right)^{2}} \\
p_{n} & =\frac{\pi}{2 N}(2 n-1)
\end{aligned}
$$

The initial state is set as $|\psi(0)\rangle=\otimes_{n}|0\rangle_{n}$. At $k=M / 2$ and $N \rightarrow \infty$, we find $\epsilon_{n}^{k} \rightarrow 0$, which denotes the quantum phase transition for the corresponding static system.

We apply the unitary time-evolution operator in the Arnoldi iteration procedure at each step. It is written as

$$
\hat{U}^{k}=\prod_{p=1}^{N / 2}\left[\cos \left(h_{n}^{k} \Delta t\right)-i\left(\hat{Z}^{n} \frac{\epsilon_{n}^{k}}{h_{n}^{k}}+\hat{X}^{n} \frac{v_{n}^{k}}{h_{n}^{k}}\right) \sin \left(h_{n}^{k} \Delta t\right)\right]
$$

where $h_{n}^{k}=\left[\left(\epsilon_{n}^{k}\right)^{2}+\left(v_{n}^{k}\right)^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}$.

# Full orthogonalization procedure 

The Arnoldi iteration procedure described in the main body involves large numerical errors and we use the full orthogonalization [6]. For a given initial basis $\left|K_{0}^{k}\right\rangle$ at each time step $k$ and a given set of the Krylov basis $\left|K_{n}^{k-1}\right\rangle$ $(n=0,1, \ldots, k-1)$ at $k-1$, we produce the set at the next step $k$ as

$$
\left|K_{n}^{k}\right\rangle \sqrt{1-\left|z_{n-1}^{k-1}\right|^{2}}=\hat{U}^{k}\left|K_{n-1}^{k-1}\right\rangle-\sum_{m=0}^{n-1}\left|K_{m}^{k}\right\rangle\left\langle K_{m}^{k}\right| \hat{U}^{k}\left|K_{n-1}^{k-1}\right\rangle \quad(n=1,2, \ldots, k)
$$

The time-evolved state $\left|\psi^{k}\right\rangle$ is calculated independently as $\left|\psi^{k}\right\rangle=\hat{U}^{k-1}\left|\psi^{k-1}\right\rangle$, and we take the overlap $\left\langle n \mid \varphi^{k}\right\rangle=$ $\left\langle K_{n}^{k} \mid \psi^{k}\right\rangle$ to calculate the spread complexity.

## KRYLOV METHOD FOR PERIODIC SYSTEMS
## Time evolution in extended space

We consider a periodic Hamiltonian satisfying $\hat{H}(t)=\hat{H}(t+T)$. It can be decomposed as

$$
\hat{H}(t)=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty} \hat{H}_{m} e^{-i m \Omega t}
$$

where $\Omega=2 \pi / T$. Although $|\psi(t)\rangle$ is not necessarily a periodic function, $|\psi(s, t)\rangle$ in Eq. (1) is periodic in $t$ if we choose $|\phi(t)\rangle$ as a periodic state, and we can write

$$
|\psi(s, t)\rangle=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}\left|\psi_{m}(s)\right\rangle e^{-i m \Omega t}
$$

The initial condition $|\psi(0, t)\rangle=|\phi(t)\rangle$ gives us the relation

$$
|\phi(t)\rangle=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}\left|\psi_{m}(0)\right\rangle e^{-i m \Omega t}
$$

Furthermore, setting $t=0$, we obtain

$$
|\psi(0)\rangle=\sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}\left|\psi_{m}(0)\right\rangle
$$

A possible simplest choice is

$$
\left|\psi_{m}(0)\right\rangle=|\psi(0)\rangle \delta_{m, 0}
$$

which corresponds to choosing $|\phi(t)\rangle=|\psi(0)\rangle$.
By using the periodicity with respect to $t$, we consider the Fourier decomposition in Eq. (S123). The transformed state satisfies

$$
i \partial_{s}\left|\psi_{m}(s)\right\rangle=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\hat{H}_{m-n}-\delta_{m, n} m \Omega\right)\left|\psi_{n}(s)\right\rangle
$$

According to the standard procedure, we extend the Hilbert space to the Hilbert-Floquet, or Sambe, space. We define the state vector in the extended space as

$$
|\Psi(s)\rangle=\sum_{m}\left|\psi_{m}(s)\right\rangle \otimes|m\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\vdots \\
\left|\psi_{1}(s)\right\rangle \\
\left|\psi_{0}(s)\right\rangle \\
\left|\psi_{-1}(s)\right\rangle \\
\vdots
\end{array}\right)
$$

and the inner product $\left\langle\left\langle\Psi^{\prime}(s) \mid \Psi(s)\right\rangle\right\rangle=\sum_{m}\left\langle\psi_{m}^{\prime}(s) \mid \psi_{m}(s)\right\rangle$ is naturally defined from this representation. The Schrödinger equation reads

$$
i \partial_{s}|\Psi(s)\rangle=(\hat{\mathcal{H}}-\hat{\mathcal{N}} \Omega)|\Psi(s)\rangle
$$

where

$$
\hat{\mathcal{H}}-\hat{\mathcal{N}} \Omega=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc}
\ddots & \ddots & \ddots & & \\
\ddots & \hat{H}_{0}-\Omega & \hat{H}_{1} & \hat{H}_{2} & \\
\ddots & \hat{H}_{-1} & \hat{H}_{0} & \hat{H}_{1} & \ddots \\
& \hat{H}_{-2} & \hat{H}_{-1} & \hat{H}_{0}+\Omega & \\
& & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots
\end{array}\right)
$$

In this infinite Hamiltonian matrix, the $(m, n)$-block is given by $\hat{H}_{m-n}-\delta_{m, n} m \Omega$. The initial condition corresponding to Eq. (S126) is given by

$$
|\Psi(0)\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\vdots \\
0 \\
|\psi(0)\rangle \\
0 \\
\vdots
\end{array}\right)
$$

Since the effective Hamiltonian in the extended space is independent of $s$, we can apply the standard Krylov method for time-independent generators. We set the initial basis as the initial state:

$$
\left|K_{0}\right\rangle=|\Psi(0)\rangle
$$

Then, higher-order basis elements are constructed through the recurrence relation

$$
\left|K_{k+1}\right\rangle b_{k+1}=(\hat{\mathcal{H}}-\hat{\mathcal{N}} \Omega)\left|K_{k}\right\rangle-\left|K_{k}\right\rangle a_{k}-\left|K_{k-1}\right\rangle b_{k}
$$

where $a_{k}=\left\langle\left\langle K_{k}\right|(\hat{\mathcal{H}}-\hat{\mathcal{N}} \Omega)\right| K_{k}\right\rangle$ and $b_{k}=\left\langle\left\langle K_{k-1}\right|(\hat{\mathcal{H}}-\hat{\mathcal{N}} \Omega)\right| K_{k}\right\rangle$.
Suppose that we can find the Krylov basis and that the number of the basis elements, the Krylov dimension, is given by $d$. Then, using the matrix $\hat{F}=\left(\left|K_{0}\right\rangle,\left|K_{1}\right\rangle, \ldots,\left|K_{d-1}\right\rangle\right)$, the effective Hamiltonian is transformed as

$$
(\hat{\mathcal{H}}-\hat{\mathcal{N}} \Omega) \hat{F}=\hat{F} \hat{\mathcal{L}}
$$

where

$$
\hat{\mathcal{L}}=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
a_{0} & b_{1} & 0 & & \\
b_{1} & a_{1} & b_{2} & & \\
0 & b_{2} & a_{2} & & \\
& & \ddots & & \\
& & & a_{d-2} & b_{d-1} \\
& & & b_{d-1} & a_{d-1}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and the state is written as

$$
|\Psi(s)\rangle=\hat{F}|\Phi(s)\rangle=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1}\left|K_{k}\right\rangle \Phi_{k}(s)
$$

Note that $|\Phi(s)\rangle=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1}|k\rangle \Phi_{k}(s)$ follows the Schrödinger equation with the generator $\hat{\mathcal{L}}$ and is written as

$$
|\Phi(s)\rangle=e^{-i s \hat{\mathcal{L}}}|0\rangle
$$

with the initial condition

$$
|0\rangle=|\Phi(0)\rangle=\left(\begin{array}{c}
1 \\
0 \\
\vdots \\
0
\end{array}\right)
$$

Now, we go back to the original Hilbert space. The state $|\psi(s, t)\rangle$ is generally written as

$$
|\psi(s, t)\rangle=\hat{\mathcal{I}} e^{-i \hat{\mathcal{M}} \Omega t} \hat{F} e^{-i \hat{\mathcal{L}} s}|0\rangle=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1} \hat{\mathcal{I}} e^{-i \hat{\mathcal{M}} \Omega t}\left|K_{k}\right\rangle\left\langle k\right| e^{-i s \hat{\mathcal{L}}}|0\rangle
$$

where

$$
\hat{\mathcal{I}}=\left(\hat{I}_{N}, \hat{I}_{N}, \ldots\right)
$$

When the state is written in the standard Krylov form

$$
|\psi(s, t)\rangle=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1}\left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle \Phi_{k}(s)=\sum_{k=0}^{d-1}\left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle\left\langle k\right| e^{-i s \hat{\mathcal{L}}}|0\rangle
$$

the basis $\left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle$ is defined as

$$
\left|K_{k}(t)\right\rangle=\sum_{m} e^{-i m \Omega t}\left\langle m \mid K_{k}\right\rangle
$$

and satisfies the orthonormal relation

$$
\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{T} d t\left\langle K_{k}(t) \mid K_{l}(t)\right\rangle=\delta_{k, l}
$$

This condition corresponds to extending the Hilbert space. States $|\psi\rangle e^{-i m \Omega t}$ with $m=0, \pm 1, \ldots$ are distinguished with each other.

# Lipkin-Meshkov-Glick model 

As an example, we consider the Hamiltonian in Eq. (15). The effective Hamiltonian is given by

$$
\hat{\mathcal{H}}-\hat{\mathcal{M}} \Omega=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
\ddots & \ddots & \ddots & & \\
\ddots & \hat{H}_{0}-\Omega & -i \hat{P} & 0 & \\
\ddots & i \hat{P} & \hat{H}_{0} & -i \hat{P} & \ddots \\
& 0 & i \hat{P} & \hat{H}_{0}+\Omega \\
& & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots
\end{array}\right)
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \hat{H}_{0}=-\frac{2 J}{N}(\hat{H})^{2} \\
& \hat{P}=h \hat{S}^{\varphi}
\end{aligned}
$$

The explicit form of the Hamiltonian is denoted by using a fixed basis. We use the $z$-basis set $\{|\mu\rangle\}_{\mu=0,1, \ldots, N}$ satisfying

$$
\hat{S}^{z}|\mu\rangle=\left(\frac{N}{2}-\mu\right)|\mu\rangle
$$

When the initial state is given by $|0\rangle$, we choose the first Krylov basis as

$$
\left|K_{0}\right\rangle=|\mu=0\rangle \otimes|m=0\rangle
$$

We expand each basis as

$$
\left|K_{k}\right\rangle=\sum_{\mu=0}^{N} \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}|\mu\rangle \otimes|m\rangle f_{k}(\mu, m)
$$

Then, the recurrence relation is written as

$$
\begin{aligned}
b_{k+1} f_{k+1}(\mu, m)= & {\left[-\frac{N J}{2}\left(1-\frac{2 \mu}{N}\right)^{2}-m \Omega-a_{k}\right] f_{k}(\mu, m)-b_{k} f_{k-1}(\mu, m) } \\
& -\frac{i h}{2} \sqrt{\mu(N+1-\mu)}\left[f_{k}(\mu-1, m+1)-f_{k}(\mu-1, m-1)\right] \\
& -\frac{i h}{2} \sqrt{(\mu+1)(N-\mu)}\left[f_{k}(\mu+1, m+1)-f_{k}(\mu+1, m-1)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The Lanczos coefficients are determined from the orthonormality condition

$$
\sum_{\mu=0}^{N} \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty} f_{k}^{z}(\mu, m) f_{l}(\mu, m)=\delta_{k, l}
$$

When the modulated field is changed from $\sin \Omega t$ to $\cos \Omega t$ in Eq. (15), the recurrence relation is slightly modified as

$$
\begin{aligned}
b_{k+1} f_{k+1}(\mu, m)= & {\left[-\frac{N J}{2}\left(1-\frac{2 \mu}{N}\right)^{2}-m \Omega-a_{k}\right] f_{k}(\mu, m)-b_{k} f_{k-1}(\mu, m) } \\
& -\frac{h}{2} \sqrt{\mu(N+1-\mu)}\left[f_{k}(\mu-1, m+1)+f_{k}(\mu-1, m-1)\right] \\
& -\frac{h}{2} \sqrt{(\mu+1)(N-\mu)}\left[f_{k}(\mu+1, m+1)+f_{k}(\mu+1, m-1)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

We confirm that the result of the Lanczos coefficients is basically unchanged.

abstract:
Krylov subspace methods in quantum dynamics identify the minimal subspace in
which a process unfolds. To date, their use is restricted to time evolutions
governed by time-independent generators. We introduce a generalization valid
for driven quantum systems governed by a time-dependent Hamiltonian that maps
the evolution to a diffusion problem in a one-dimensional lattice with
nearest-neighbor hopping probabilities that are inhomogeneous and time
dependent. This representation is used to establish a novel class of
fundamental limits to the quantum speed of evolution and operator growth. We
also discuss generalizations of the algorithm, adapted to discretized time
evolutions and periodic Hamiltonians, with applications to many-body systems.
